conformal mappings, Schwarz lemma

Let f(z)f\p{z}f(z) be a one-to-one continuous mapping from the closed annulus

{1≤∣z∣≤R}\set{1 \leq \abs{z} \leq R}{1≤∣z∣≤R}

onto the closed annulus

{1≤∣z∣≤S}\set{1 \leq \abs{z} \leq S}{1≤∣z∣≤S}

such that fff is analytic on the open annulus {1<∣z∣<R}\set{1 < \abs{z} < R}{1<∣z∣<R}. Prove S=RS = RS=R.
Solution.

Denote A(r,R)={r≤∣z∣≤R}A\p{r, R} = \set{r \leq \abs{z} \leq R}A(r,R)={r≤∣z∣≤R} and so f ⁣:A(1,R)→A(1,S)\func{f}{A\p{1,R}}{A\p{1,S}}f:A(1,R)→A(1,S) is a conformal mapping. fff maps ∂A(1,R)\partial A\p{1, R}∂A(1,R) to ∂A(1,S)\partial A\p{1, S}∂A(1,S). If fff maps ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1 to ∣z∣=S\abs{z} = S∣z∣=S, then we can post-compose fff with Sz\frac{S}{z}zS​. This inversion maps ∣z∣=S\abs{z} = S∣z∣=S to ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1, and so without loss of generality, we can assume that fff maps ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1 to itself.

Consider

g(z)=1f(1/z‾)‾,g\p{z} = \frac{1}{\conj{f\p{1/\conj{z}}}},g(z)=f(1/z)​1​,

which is holomorphic via the Cauchy-Riemann equations and because fff never vanishes. Observe that if ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1, then 1/z‾=z1/\conj{z} = z1/z=z and so

g(z)=1f(1/z‾)‾=1f(z)‾,=f(z).g\p{z} = \frac{1}{\conj{f\p{1/\conj{z}}}} = \frac{1}{\conj{f\p{z}}}, = f\p{z}.g(z)=f(1/z)​1​=f(z)​1​,=f(z).

Thus, fff and ggg are continuous and agree at ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1 and are holomorphic on their respective domains, they extend by the Schwarz reflection principle to a single holomorphic function A(R−1,R)→A(S−1,S)A\p{R^{-1}, R} \to A\p{S^{-1}, S}A(R−1,R)→A(S−1,S), and we will just denote this extension as fff.

Notice that Sf(zR)Sf\p{\frac{z}{R}}Sf(Rz​) is a holomorphic function A(1,R2)→A(1,S2)A\p{1, R^2} \to A\p{1, S^2}A(1,R2)→A(1,S2), so we may repeat this argument. By induction, we obtain a holomorphic extension of fff to the interior of A(R1−2n,R)→A(S1−2n,S)A\p{R^{1-2^n}, R} \to A\p{S^{1-2^n}, S}A(R1−2n,R)→A(S1−2n,S) for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. Thus, fff extends to a holomorphic function B(0,R)∖{0}→B(0,S)∖{0}B\p{0, R} \setminus \set{0} \to B\p{0, S} \setminus \set{0}B(0,R)∖{0}→B(0,S)∖{0}. Since ∣f(z)∣≤S\abs{f\p{z}} \leq S∣f(z)∣≤S on the entire punctured disk, fff extends holomorphically to a holomorphic function on B(0,R)B\p{0, R}B(0,R). From our extension, we know that

∣f(R1−2n)∣=S1−2n→n→∞0,\abs{f\p{R^{1-2^n}}} = S^{1-2^n} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0,∣∣​f(R1−2n)∣∣​=S1−2nn→∞​0,

so f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0, so fff is a holomorphic function B(0,R)→B(0,S)B\p{0, R} \to B\p{0, S}B(0,R)→B(0,S). By applying the Schwarz lemma to 1Sf(Rz)\frac{1}{S}f\p{Rz}S1​f(Rz), we have

∣1Sf(Rz)∣≤∣z∣  ⟹  ∣f(z)∣≤SR∣z∣.\abs{\frac{1}{S}f\p{Rz}} \leq \abs{z} \implies \abs{f\p{z}} \leq \frac{S}{R} \abs{z}.∣∣​S1​f(Rz)∣∣​≤∣z∣⟹∣f(z)∣≤RS​∣z∣.

Setting z=R1−2nz = R^{1-2^n}z=R1−2n,

S1−2n≤SRR1−2n  ⟹  S−2n≤R−2n  ⟹  R≤S.S^{1-2^n} \leq \frac{S}{R} R^{1-2^n} \implies S^{-2^n} \leq R^{-2^n} \implies R \leq S.S1−2n≤RS​R1−2n⟹S−2n≤R−2n⟹R≤S.

Since fff is a continuous bijection from the compact space A(1,R)A\p{1, R}A(1,R) to the Hausdorff space A(1,S)A\p{1, S}A(1,S), it is a homeomorphism. On the interior, fff is an injective holomorphic function, so by the inverse function theorem, fff is a biholomorphism on the interiors. Hence, we may apply this argument to f−1 ⁣:A(1,S)→A(1,R)\func{f^{-1}}{A\p{1, S}}{A\p{1, R}}f−1:A(1,S)→A(1,R) to see that S≤RS \leq RS≤R by symmetry. Thus, S=RS = RS=R, which completes the proof.
